sources.data_found: 2022 Degree Completion Data: Computer Science (613 Bachelors, 215 Masters, 32 PhDs) + Computer & Information Sciences (71 Bachelors, 172 Masters, 9 PhDs). Used to estimate enrollment.

student_data.notes: Enrollment estimated from 2022 degree completions (latest auditable data) for 'Computer Science' and 'Computer & Information Sciences' CIP codes (covering both Courant and Tandon schools). Undergrad estimation: 684 degrees awarded * 4 years = 2,736. Grad (MS) estimation: 387 degrees awarded * 2 years = 774. PhD estimation: 41 degrees awarded * 5.5 years = 225.

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: Greene Cluster: 33 nodes x 4 GPUs per node. These are Turing-architecture workstation cards (similar to Quadro) with 48GB VRAM, widely used for AI inference and training at NYU.

gpu_resources.notes:
Counts based on the official 'Greene' supercomputer launch specifications (2020), which remains the primary university-wide cluster. 

Calculations:
- A100: 14 nodes * 4 GPUs = 56 (Assumed 40GB as they were launch-era A100s; CDS listing of '48 A100s' suggests they have a large allocation of this pool).
- V100: 12 nodes * 4 GPUs = 48.
- RTX 8000: 33 nodes * 4 GPUs = 132.

Note: NYU is a partner in the 'Empire AI' consortium (announced 2024) which will provide H100 access, but this hardware is shared statewide and likely not hosted on the NYU Washington Square campus yet. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

analysis_notes: NYU's specific node counts are derived from the Greene launch press release as current live status pages (sites.google.com/nyu-hpc) are occasionally login-gated. Student counts aggregate both the Courant Institute (Arts & Sciences) and Tandon School of Engineering CS programs via DataUSA completion proxies.
